Bump n=
odded as he opened a storage closet and pulled out a large
panel. Pushing a=
 few buttons on it it began to glow slightly as it
unfolded into a temporar=
y antigravity suspensor bed.

"I will be right back." he said, "I am going =
to retrieve Nightlight.
We still have a bit of work to do it seems."

> <OL=
D>

> Tucson nodds.
>
> "Thank you Legacy, everyone, I know it's hard to u=
nderstand things that we normally could never understand, but it is this co=
mmon ground which will keep us together as a faction, something Hydras does=
 not have, nor will ever have. I also understand your reservations on the m=
atter. I can tell just by the tones of your voices, but I also comprehend t=
he reason behind it and it's only normal to have reservations. I am not off=
ended by your true feelings, but thankful you are willing to give Perceptor=
 the chance to prove himself worthy."
>
> Before Tucson had been upgraded t=
o a Prime, this sort of talk would often anger him to the point of grave an=
noyance. He'd often speak up and stick up for those being riddiculed and wh=
enever necesary, he probably would have lost his temper all together and de=
cked the offender right there and then. But now, he realizes those feelings=
 did not come through. Something was definitely changing. Instead of being =
his old self, he was evolving into someone new, wiser, more tolerant, and a=
 lot more calm as an individual. Yet, his toughness was still there, along =
with his courage, and will to fight. He could not yet understand the meanin=
g of these changes, and for whatever reason, he knew they were for the bett=
er. He now turns his head in Legacy's direction.
>
> " Even as a Prime, I'm=
 still in the process of learning. I don't think I'll ever stop learning. O=
ne thing I have to admit, if I were still my old self now, short tempered, =
quick to be critical, I may have blown the roof off the Ark, and retorted a=
dversely. But now, I couldn't find it in my spark to react as such. I'm cha=
nging, and as I change, I can feel the pressense of Optimus Prime. I often =
feel that if I could see my shadow, it would appear as his once did, long a=
go. Why is that? I know I'm not Optimus, yet there is a part of me that fee=
ls that he's within me somehow. Legacy, is there something about me that ev=
en I do not know? I'm very curious to find out."

<NEW>

Legacy watched Tus=
con impassively, his single optic glowing with a
focused light. "Your react=
ion is . . . curious." Legacy said in his
normal icy tones, "Change is inev=
itable,  predictable and often times
beneficial. Logic demands that we adap=
t to what we cannot control and
be a part of change rather than a victim of=
 it."

Legacy turned to observe Perceptor, "I am sure we shall all keep a
w=
atchful optic on him, and adapt our responses to his actions."

Santon nodd=
ed as he crossed his arms, "Yep. I agree. If you vouch for
him Tuscon then =
I will give him the benefit of the doubt, but I won't
take my optic off of =
him until he proves it to me he's trust worthy."

Torca, who had stepped ba=
ck in the room merely nodded at Tuscon,
holding his own council for the mom=
ent on how he felt about
Perceptor's presence. Instead he chose to change t=
he subject, "I will
be sending the Fuzors out on patrol. There is no tellin=
g what Hydras
is doing while we are all sitting here watching you and Rodim=
us
recover."
